Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Salim satisfied the residency requirement under Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act and whether the Citizenship Judge provided adequate reasons
Application_Facts: Mr. Salim was physically present in Canada for 1099-1101 days but omitted declaring six trips abroad
Decision_Outcome: Minister's appeal granted; decision remanded for redetermination
Remedy_Requested: Redetermination of citizenship application with proper reasoning
Court_Ruling: Appeal granted due to inadequate reasons provided by the Citizenship Judge
Defendant_Behavior: Failure to declare international trips, leading to questions about residency compliance
Grounds_for_Claim: Inadequate reasoning by Citizenship Judge on residency calculation and unexplained treatment of unreported absences
Legal_Standard: Test for residency includes physical presence or connection to Canada (per Koo (Re)); judges must provide adequate reasons under Section 14(2)
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence duration, credibility of travel declarations, connection to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Failure to meet procedural fairness through insufficient explanation of residency assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Omission of six trips raises concerns about completeness and honesty of application
Evidence_Used: Travel records, application forms, hearing testimony
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 5(1)(c), Section 14(2) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Basis: Calculation of 1095 required days within four-year period
Evidence_Assessed: Declared and undeclared absences from Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturn of approval and referral back for proper assessment
Governing_Rule: Applicant must have 1095 days of physical presence; decisions must include transparent, adequate reasons
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clarity on how unreported absences were treated in residency calculation
Outcome: Case referred back to Citizenship Judge Duguay for redetermination with clear reasoning
Harm_Assessment: Risk of improper citizenship grant due to flawed residency evaluation
Cause_Description: Minister appealed due to inadequate reasoning in the citizenship approval decision
Evidence_Handling: Incomplete disclosure of travel history affected reliability of residency claim
Evidence_Issues: Undeclared international trips undermined accuracy of residency declaration
Residency_Compliance: Marginal compliance (1099â€“1101 days) but compromised by lack of transparency
Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of trips may constitute misrepresentation affecting application integrity
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian citizenship law
Evidence_Assessment: Judge failed to explain how evidence of absences was weighed
Decision_Rationale: Ambiguous reasoning breaches procedural fairness; remand required for proper analysis
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to account for or explain impact of non-declared absences
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo (Re) test for residency; adequacy of reasons under administrative law
